section.title: Resolving Git Merge Conflicts During Upgrade
Introduction
section.para: When you perform an upgrade, &kw-hos; attempts to incorporate new or updated configuration information on top of your existing environment. However, if you have made certain changes to your environment, &kw-hos; cannot automatically determine whether to keep your changes or drop them in favour of the new or updated configurations that it wants to put in place. This will result in a merge conflict occurring during upgrade and it will be up to you to manually resolve the conflict before the upgrade can proceed.

This document gives an overview of how to approach the issue of merge conflicts, showing general procedures for determining where the conflict is occurring, alternative methods for resolution, and a fallback procedure for the case where the resolution goes wrong and you need to start from scratch.

For a general overview of how &kw-hos; uses Git, see the introductory article in the Installation section . In particular, note how the site branch is the one most used by the end-user, while the ardana branch contains the "upstream" source code corresponding to the contents of the ~/openstack directory on a pristine fresh installation.

section.title: Identifying the occurrence of a merge conflict
section.para: If you hit a merge conflict during upgrade, you will observe output similar to the following on the console:
section.screen: Auto-merging ardana/ansible/roles/nova-compute-esx/defaults/main.yml Auto-merging ardana/ansible/roles/nova-common/templates/nova.conf.j2 CONFLICT (content): Merge conflict in ardana/ansible/roles/nova-common/templates/nova.conf.j2 Auto-merging ardana/ansible/roles/nova-cli/tasks/availability_zones.yml Auto-merging ardana/ansible/roles/nova-api/templates/api-paste.ini.j2

section.title: Examining Conflicts
section.para: Use git status to see the discover the source of the problem:
section.screen:
... new file: tech-preview/entry-scale-kvm-mml/data/swift/rings.yml modified: tech-preview/mid-scale/README.md modified: tech-preview/mid-scale/data/control_plane.yml
Unmerged paths: (use "git add/rm <file>..." as appropriate to mark resolution)
both modified: ardana/ansible/roles/nova-common/templates/nova.conf.j2
section.para: Edit the file ardana/ansible/roles/nova-common/templates/nova.conf.j2 to see the conflict markers:

This indicates that &kw-hos-phrase; 3.0 is trying to set the value of metadata_proxy_shared_secret to be {{ neutron_metadata_proxy_shared_secret }} whereas previously you have set its value to top_secret_password111.

section.title: Examining differences between your current version and the previous upstream version
section.para: Typically, the previous upstream version will be the last-but-one commit on the ardana branch. This version will have been created during the initial installation of your cloud (or perhaps during a previous upgrade). So in total, there are three significant versions of the file:

listitem.para: The previous "upstream" version on the ardana branch.
Your current version on the site branch.
The new "upstream" version on the ardana branch.

section.para: You can identify the previous "upstream" version using git merge-base
section.screen: git merge-base ardana site 2eda1df48e2822533c50f80f5bfd7a9d788bdf73
section.para: And then use git log to see where this commit occurs in the history of the ardana branch.
section.screen:
git log ardana -- commit 22cfa83f3526baf30b3697e971a712930f86f611 Author: Openstack git user <openstack@example.com> Date: Mon Jan 18 00:30:33 2016 +0000
New drop
commit 2eda1df48e2822533c50f80f5bfd7a9d788bdf73 Author: Openstack git user <openstack@example.com> Date: Sun Jan 17 19:14:01 2016 +0000
New drop
section.para: In this instance, we can see that the relevant commit is in fact the last-but-one commit and so we can use the simplified name ardana^1 to identify that commit.
section.screen: git diff ardana^1 HEAD -- ardana/ansible/roles/nova-common/templates/nova.conf.j2
section.para: In the diff output, you should be able to see how you changed the value for metadata_proxy_shared_secret from unset to top_secret_password111:

section.title: Examining differences between your current version and the new upstream version
section.para: To compare your change with the new upstream version from &kw-hos-phrase; on the ardana branch you can use git diff HEAD ardana -- <<path/to/file>>:
section.screen: git diff HEAD ardana -- ardana/ansible/roles/nova-common/templates/nova.conf.j2
section.para: In the extract of output below, you can see your value top_secret_password111 and the new value {{ neutron_metadata_proxy_shared_secret }} that &kw-hos-phrase; wants to set.

section.title: Examining differences between the new upstream version and the previous upstream version
section.para: To compare the new upstream version from &kw-hos-phrase; with the previous upstream version from your initial install (or previous upgrade):
section.screen: git diff $(git merge-base ardana HEAD) ardana -- ardana/ansible/roles/nova-common/templates/nova.conf.j2
section.para: In the extract of output below, you can see the new upstream value {{ neutron_metadata_proxy_shared_secret }} that &kw-hos-phrase; wants to set and the previous upstream value unset.

section.title: Using stage markers to view clean versions of files (without conflict markers)
section.para: You can use the git show command with stage markers to view files without having conflict markers embedded in them. Stage 1 is the previous upstream version (:1), stage 2 is your current version (:2) while stage 3 is the new upstream version (:3).
section.screen: git show :1:ardana/ansible/roles/nova-common/templates/nova.conf.j2
... admin_username = {{ neutron_admin_username }} metadata_proxy_shared_secret = unset neutron_auth_strategy = keystone neutron_ca_certificates_file = /etc/ssl/certs/ca-certificates.crt ...
git show :2:ardana/ansible/roles/nova-common/templates/nova.conf.j2

... admin_username = {{ neutron_admin_username }} metadata_proxy_shared_secret = top_secret_password111 neutron_auth_strategy = keystone neutron_ca_certificates_file = /etc/ssl/certs/ca-certificates.crt ...
git show :3:ardana/ansible/roles/nova-common/templates/nova.conf.j2

section.title: Resolving the conflict
section.para: There are two approaches to resolving the conflict:

listitem.para: Edit the merged file containing the conflict markers, keeping the change you want to preserve and removing the conflict markers and any changes you want to discard.
Take the new upstream version of the file and re-apply any changes you would like to keep from your current version.

section.title: Resolving the conflict - editing the file containing the conflict markers
section.para: Edit the file ardana/ansible/roles/nova-common/templates/nova.conf.j2 and if you want to maintain your change, then delete the lines in bold below:
Your file should now look like this:

section.title: Resolving the conflict - re-applying your changes to new upstream version
section.para: Create a copy of the new upstream version (see Stage 3 above) in your working directory:
section.screen: git show :3:ardana/ansible/roles/nova-common/templates/nova.conf.j2 > \ ardana/ansible/roles/nova-common/templates/nova.conf.j2
section.para: Now edit the file ardana/ansible/roles/nova-common/templates/nova.conf.j2 and manually re-apply that changes you want.

section.title: Completing the merge procedure
section.para: You may want to check that the changes you have applied are correct. Compare the new upstream version with the version in your working directory:
section.screen: git diff ardana -- ardana/ansible/roles/nova-common/templates/nova.conf.j2
section.para: If you are happy with the resolution, you can stage your changes using:
section.screen: git add ardana/ansible/roles/nova-common/templates/nova.conf.j2
section.para: Apply the above steps to all the merge conflicts you encounter, and when you have them resolved to your satisfaction, complete the merge:
section.screen: git commit -m "complete merge"

section.title: Recovering from Errors
section.screen: git reset --hard
section.para: If the new upstream version contains files that didn't exist in the previous version, these files will be left behind - you can seem them using git status. To clean up these files, remove them and then reset:
section.screen: git rm -rf ardana git reset --hard
section.para: Alternatively, you can use git stash to save these files to transient stash queue.
